label{font-weight:700;margin-right:1%;width:31%;display:inline-block}#comment-form label:nth-child(3){margin-right:0;width:33%}#comment-form label[for=subscribe]{width:auto;margin:10px 0 20px}#comment-form .label{display:none}.x-long,a.wufoo,pre{display:block}#comment-form input[type=email],#comment-form input[type=search],#comment-form input[type=text],#comment-form input[type=url],#comment-form textarea{padding:6px;border:1px solid #ccc;box-sizing:border-box;width:100%;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:18px}#comment-form input[type=email]:focus,#comment-form input[type=search]:focus,#comment-form input[type=text]:focus,#comment-form input[type=url]:focus,#comment-form textarea:focus{background:#fff}#comment-form textarea{width:100%;min-height:200px}.hint,.subscribe-to-comments{margin:20px 0 4px;font-style:italic;font-size:16px}#launch-editor{font-size:15px;color:#999}#launch-editor i{margin-right:4px}main .x-long{margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;margin-bottom:30px}main .post-list .x-long{margin-bottom:0}.ad-center{margin:0 auto}a.wufoo .letter{-webkit-transform:scale(.45);-ms-transform:scale(.45);transform:scale(.45)}a.wufoo .byline,a.wufoo .illustration,a.wufoo .letter,a.wufoo .swirl,a.wufoo .text{opacity:.6}a.wufoo .illustration{-webkit-transform:scale(1.2);-ms-transform:scale(1.2);transform:scale(1.2)}a.wufoo .byline,a.wufoo .illustration,a.wufoo .letter,a.wufoo .text{-webkit-transition:all .6s;-ms-transition:all .6s;transition:all .6s}.new a.wufoo .byline,.new a.wufoo .illustration,.new a.wufoo .letter,.new a.wufoo .text{-webkit-transition:none;-ms-transition:none;transition:none}a.wufoo.complete .letter{opacity:1;-webkit-transform:scale(.5);-ms-transform:scale(.5);transform:scale(.5)}a.wufoo.complete .letter:nth-of-type(2){-webkit-transition-delay:.2s;-ms-transition-delay:.2s;transition-delay:.2s}a.wufoo.complete .letter:nth-of-type(3){-webkit-transition-delay:.3s;-ms-transition-delay:.3s;transition-delay:.3s}a.wufoo.complete .text{opacity:1;-webkit-transform:scale(1);-ms-transform:scale(1);transform:scale(1);-webkit-transition-delay:.5s;-ms-transition-delay:.5s;transition-delay:.5s}article a.wufoo{margin:20px 0}input[type=text],input[type=password],textarea{border:1px solid a{background:#69c773;border:0;border-bottom:3px solid rgba(73,134,18,.3);color:#fff;font-weight:400;font-size:20px;transition:border-color 1s;text-decoration:none;white-space:nowrap}#comment-form a:hover,.green-button:active,.green-button:focus,.green-button:hover,.pagination a:active,.pagination a:focus,.pagination a:hover{border-color:rgba(73,134,18,.7)}@media (max-width:768px){#comment-form a{font-size:16px}}pre,pre[class*=language-]{background:#fff!important;padding:0!important;-webkit-tab-size:2;-moz-tab-size:2;tab-size:2}code{padding:2px img{display:none}}.gb-links{text-transform:lowercase;margin-top:-20px}.gb-links a{display:inline-block;margin-right:20px;background:rgba(255,255,255,.8);padding:2px 6px;border:1px solid code[class*=language-],pre[class*=language-]{color:#000;background:0 0;text-shadow:0 1px #fff;font-family:Consolas,Monaco,'Andale Mono','Ubuntu Mono',monospace;text-align:left;white-space:pre;word-spacing:normal;word-break:normal;word-wrap:normal;line-height:1.5;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;-webkit-hyphens:none;-moz-hyphens:none;-ms-hyphens:none;hyphens:none}code[class*=language-] ::-moz-selection,code[class*=language-]::-moz-selection,pre[class*=language-] ::-moz-selection,pre[class*=language-]::-moz-selection{text-shadow:none;background:#b3d4fc}code[class*=language-] ::selection,code[class*=language-]::selection,pre[class*=language-] ::selection,pre[class*=language-]::selection{text-shadow:none;background:#b3d4fc}@media print{code[class*=language-],pre[class*=language-]{text-shadow:none}}pre[class*=language-]{padding:1em;margin:.5em 0;overflow:auto}:not(pre)>code[class*=language-],pre[class*=language-]{background:#f5f2f0}:not(pre)>code[class*=language-]{padding:.1em;border-radius:.3em;white-space:normal}.token.cdata,.token.comment,.token.doctype,.token.prolog{color:#708090}.token.punctuation{color:#999}.namespace{opacity:.7}.token.boolean,.token.constant,.token.deleted,.token.number,.token.property,.token.symbol,.token.tag{color:#905}.token.attr-name,.token.builtin,.token.char,.token.inserted,.token.selector,.token.string{color:#690}.language-css .token.string,.style .token.string,.token.entity,.token.operator,.token.url{color:#a67f59;background:hsla(0,0%,100%,.5)}.token.atrule,.token.attr-value,.token.keyword{color:#07a}.token.function{color:#DD4A68}.token.important,.token.regex,.token.variable{color:#e90}.token.bold,.token.important{font-weight:700}.token.italic{font-style:italic}.token.entity{cursor:help}</style>

   <div class="center clear">
    <!-- main content column -->
    <main id="main">
     <!--CONTENT-->
     <div class="oreilly-callout" style="background:#7372a5;">
      <a href="http://www.oreilly.com/pub/cpc/77171" style="color: #fff;"><i class="fa fa-arrow-circle-o-right"></i> &nbsp;<strong style="color:yellow">Building Resilient Systems on AWS</strong>: Learn how to design and implement a resilient, highly available, fault-tolerant infrastructure on AWS.</a>
     </div>
     <style>
.oreilly-callout {
background: #231f20;
margin-bottom: 30px;
padding: 5px 10px;
border-radius: 6px;
display: none;
}
.oreilly-callout a {
color: #7ac9ed;
text-decoration: none;
display: block;
}
.oreilly-callout a code {
color: #fff;
background-color: #000;
margin-left: 10px;
}
</style>
     <article itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
      <h1 itemprop="headline" class="offscreen">Send Text Messages with PHP</h1>
      <div class="meta" id="meta">
        By 
       <a href="http://davidwalsh.name" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">David Walsh</span></a>&nbsp;on 
       <time itemprop="datePublished">August 15, 2011</time> &nbsp; 
       <ul class="social-icons" id="single-social" data-url="https://davidwalsh.name/send-text-message" data-title="Send Text Messages with PHP" data-twitter-handle="">
        <li><a href="#comments" class="discuss" title="Join the discussion"><i class="fa fa-comment" aria-hidden="true"></i></a><span>66</span></li>
        <li><a href="javascript:;" rel="nofollow" class="twitter get-count soc" title="Share on Twitter!"><i class="fa fa-twitter" aria-hidden="true"></i></a></li>
        <li><a href="javascript:;" rel="nofollow" class="facebook get-count soc" title="Share on Facebook!"><i class="fa fa-facebook" aria-hidden="true"></i></a></li>
        <li><a href="javascript:;" rel="nofollow" class="google-plus soc" title="Share on Google Plus!"><i class="fa fa-google-plus" aria-hidden="true"></i></a></li>
        <li><a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https://davidwalsh.name/send-text-message" target="_blank" class="reddit" title="Share on Reddit"><i class="fa fa-reddit" aria-hidden="true"></i></a></li>
        <li><a href="#top" class="top" title="Go to top"><i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up" aria-hidden="true"></i></a></li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="offscreen"></div>
      <!-- content -->
      <img src="https://davidwalsh.name/demo/sms-text.png" alt="Text Message" class="image"> 
      <p>Kids these days, I tell ya. &nbsp;All they care about is the technology. &nbsp;The video games. &nbsp;The bottled water. &nbsp;Oh, and the texting, always the texting. &nbsp;Back in my day, all we had was...OK, I had all of these things too. &nbsp;But I still don't get the volume of texts that I hear my younger female cousins send. &nbsp;Thousands and thousands of them each month. &nbsp;WTF are all of these texts for? &nbsp;Here's a thought:</p> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>omg did you hear?</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>no wut</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>omg i can't believe you didn't hear</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>lol tell me!</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>jenny and mark were holding hands</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>omfg does john no?</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <blockquote>
       <p>ok i made it up, ur so lame</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <p>Riveting. &nbsp;Jokes aside, text messaging can be an extremely useful way to 
       <strike>
        get out of calling that person you hate calling
       </strike>&nbsp;communicate quickly and efficiently. &nbsp;Many websites are now offering text message notifications instead of email notifications, which can be nice in the case of time-sensitive information. &nbsp;After a bit of research, I found out how easy it was so send text messages using PHP, so that I can integrate text messaging into my apps! &nbsp;Let me show you how!</p> 
      <h2>The Methodology</h2> 
      <p>Unbeknownst to me, sending text messages can be as easy as sendmail, because you can send your text to an email address and it will be delivered. &nbsp;There are two pieces of information you must know: &nbsp;the phone number and the carrier's text message email domain. &nbsp;Needing to know the recipient's carrier is not ideal, but necessary. &nbsp;Luckily Kevin Jensen has <a href="http://www.venture-ware.com/kevin/web-development/email-to-sms/" rel="nofollow">compiled a list of carriers and domains</a>:</p> 
      <div class="actions">
       <a href="https://davidwalsh.name/demo/SMS-Carriers.pdf" class="demo">Download Carrier List</a>
       <div class="clear"></div>
      </div> 
      <p>Phone companies have internal lookups for phone carriers but developers like you and I don't get access to them, so knowing the carrier is &nbsp;a must. &nbsp;To send a text message, you email <code>{phoneNumber}@{carrierDomain}</code>.</p> 
      <h2>The PHP</h2> 
      <p>PHP's provided method for sending emails is the <a href="http://php.net/mail" rel="nofollow"><code>mail</code> function</a>. &nbsp;Its usage is quite simple:</p> 
      <pre class="php">
bool mail ( string $to , string $subject , string $message [, string $additional_headers [, string $additional_parameters ]] )
</pre> 
      <p>Using the mail function and the text message email format, sending a text message is as easy as:</p> 
      <pre class="php">
// Call Jenny
mail("5558675309@txt.att.net", "", "Your packaged has arrived!", "From: David Walsh &lt;david@davidwalsh.name&gt;\r\n");
</pre> 
      <p>Note that no subject line is provided, and more importantly, a FROM header is within the last parameter so that the recipient knows where the text message has been sent from.</p> 
      <p>Who knew it was that easy? &nbsp;I always assumed text messaging had its own protocol and all that magic. &nbsp;Apparently not! &nbsp;Spend a few minutes playing around with text messaging yourself; &nbsp;it's one of those things that's both neat to do and useful!</p>
      <!-- secondary ad -->
      <div class="x x-long x-secondary">
       <a href="https://tkjs.us/2qjWxOs" style="display:block;"><object data="https://davidwalsh.name/demo/track-js-2.svg?1505672116" type="image/svg+xml" style="max-width:100%;pointer-events:none;"></object></a>
      </div> 
      <!-- guest blogger -->
     </article>
     <div class="article-block" style="height:90px">
      <!-- terciary ad -->
      <div class="x x-long x-terciary">
       <div class="bsa" data-bsa="1306951|db3b221ddd8cbba67739ae3837520ffe" style="“height:90px" !important;”></div>
      </div> 
     </div>
     <div class="article-block post-more" style="“clear:both;”">
      <h2><a href="/tutorials/features">Recent Features<i class="fa fa-arrow-circle-o-right"></i></a></h2>
      <ul class="post-list small-list">
       <li data-url="https://davidwalsh.name/css-gradients" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">

        </div><span itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/ImageObject"><img data-src="https://davidwalsh.name/demo/css-gradients.png?preview" class="post-image" alt="CSS Gradients"></span>

        </div></li>
       <li data-url="https://davidwalsh.name/namespace-mootools" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">

        </div><span itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/ImageObject"><img data-src="/demo/mootools250.png?preview" class="post-image" alt="Create Namespaced Classes with MooTools"></span>
        <div class="preview">

         <p>MooTools has always gotten a bit of grief for not&nbsp;inherently&nbsp;using and standardizing namespaced-based JavaScript classes like the Dojo Toolkit does. &nbsp;Many developers create their classes as globals which is generally frowned up. &nbsp;I mostly disagree with that stance, but each to their own. &nbsp;In any event...</p>
        </div></li>

     </div>
     <div class="article-block post-more">

      <ul class="post-list small-list">

        <li id="comment-26596" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=a2e89fdce5356e7cf23699a2523cca09&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">

           <p>Unfortunately this method doesn’t work in the UK and probably only works in the US and a handful of other countries. This is because mobile operators in the UK don’t give us email addresses that send to people as texts, certainly not with the mobile number as the address. It’s a big shame as you basically have to sign up for expensive sms gateways.</p> 
          </div>
          <div class="comment-controls">

       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26549" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=4894edbdc3306ab8ff8144fe8ec6d214&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">

Only one number and one carrier though. Might have to look into Twilio for more complex implementations.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26549"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>

        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26551" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=85b9bfe7b0b198807d42981d6946a911&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://www.waynemay.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Wayne</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>This is very carrier dependant. Some carriers do not allow this, and others make this low priority, sometimes resulting in messages being late, or never delivered.</p> 
          <p>Regardless, there are the formats for the big 4:<br> Sprint <a href="mailto:phonenumber@messaging.sprintpcs.com">phonenumber@messaging.sprintpcs.com</a><br> Verizon <a href="mailto:phonenumber@vtext.com">phonenumber@vtext.com</a><br> T-Mobile <a href="mailto:phonenumber@tmomail.net">phonenumber@tmomail.net</a><br> AT&amp;T <a href="mailto:phonenumber@txt.att.net">phonenumber@txt.att.net</a></p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26551"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26552" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=8f3075dc2278a39b600098685cfae85d&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          Alex
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Any carrier information for Greece?</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26552"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26553" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=f990566be3d0986e30000fc6e5843d0b&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          David Myers
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I’ve done this before and I have a tip to eliminate some issues I’ve encountered with this method.</p> 
          <p>The first issue is that this requires the user to specify a carrier which can be annoying and even put some people off of the concept. The second issue is that using the mail function opens a socket every time it is called, so doing mass texts becomes a very big issue very fast. </p> 
          <p>To get around the first issue, you just have an array of the carrier mail servers {@vtext.com, @txt.att.net, etc} and then you just append the users cell number to the beginning of each array value when you want to send a message. To do this you have to build up an array with all of the possible carriers, but a quick wikipedia search makes this a simple task. </p> 
          <p>Now to deal with the volume issue you can just use the PEAR mail function (commonly installed along with PHP). Doing this, you can send one message to multiple addresses at the same time while only using one socket. This also allows you to send the message to every possible phone number/address very quickly. The message will only go through to the correct address and you don’t have to know who the carrier is.</p> 
          <p>As a side note, some carriers don’t interpret the FROM email headers correctly/uniformly so it’s something you definitely want to test if at all possible.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26553"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <ul class="children"> 
        <li id="comment-26558" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=51a17b9288b3466a6c1939bd836b17aa&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
         <div class="box">
          <div class="comment-user">
           Chris McKee
          </div>
          <div class="comment-content">
           <p>Seems like a good concept (even if theres no guarantee of delivery).<br> Doesn’t seem to work with O2 in the UK, which is sucky.</p> 
          </div>
          <div class="comment-controls">
           <a href="#comment-26558"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
          </div>
         </div></li>
        <!-- #comment-## --> 
        <li id="comment-26567" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=f990566be3d0986e30000fc6e5843d0b&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">

           David Myers

          </div>

       <!-- .children --> 
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26554" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=f990566be3d0986e30000fc6e5843d0b&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          David Myers
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Aaaand that didn’t format my text. Sorry for the unreadable wall of text, haha.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26554"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26559" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=a9bc7c5565bf05f528ab1b645f636d1c&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          Bastien
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I would urge caution here. From hard won experience, not all carriers will treat the sending of an email as text. Some might, some will send it as emails depending on the users data/email plan. Others simply won’t deliver the message at all</p> 
          <p>For truly reliable text messages, you will need an SMS gateway provider, twilio is a great example of this and they are easy to integrate into the site but it will cost. There are various free gateways, with varying degrees of successful delivery.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26559"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26563" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=f79401b5a3d320c3c38a961a68e273d9&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          crocodile2u
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">

       <li id="comment-26565" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=f3c24781e1d016d61ed40a45a8face0c&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">

       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26566" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=13f80c103e4cc1f5fbd39d0f5f6caa09&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://www.webresourcesdepot.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Umut Muhaddisoglu</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Great article David.</p> 
          <p>I’m also sharing a list of email-to-SMS gateway providers as a .SQL and .CSV file at: <a href="http://www.uptimerobot.com/sms.asp" rel="nofollow">http://www.uptimerobot.com/sms.asp</a> (check the bottom of the article).</p> 
          <p>This is a regularly updated list as some gateways become valid/invalid from time-to-time and it includes the prefixes/suffixes for them as well.</p> 
          <p>Hope it helps.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26566"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26568" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=d840da4b1f497c64089969eee4a1bf47&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://www.installedforyou.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Jeff</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I’ve played with this a bunch, and have several friends in the phone industry.</p> 
          <p>The email to SMS priority seems low on some carriers, what’s more, depending on the plan &amp; carrier, there are additional steps or even FEES for this.</p> 
          <p>Fido (Canada) can/used to charge up to $0.50 per message.<br> They also require the user to respond to a generic message with “READ” in order to download the remaining part(s) of the message. Not fantastic.</p> 
          <p>SMS Gateways are fairly inexpensive for a business sending messages. Individuals probably don’t want to pay the prices.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26568"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## -->

       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26580" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=f0941fbff3998e7d1b4b868395d478f6&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://www.adamsdesk.com/be/" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Adam</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I’ve been using email to SMS gateways for years now. Here is a good list of SMS gateways around the world, <a href="https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/List_of_SMS_gateways" rel="nofollow">https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/List_of_SMS_gateways</a>.</p> 
          <p>I agree though that one needs to keep in mind a lot of carriers/mobile phones do not support the subject line or from field. What I do is is add something to the SMS message to identify who the sender is.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26580"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-26583" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=9ea90ddd1bef464cf65d29ae024f9a4f&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://techore.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Patrick</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I have been doing sms’ing in the US for a little while and one big requirement that hasn’t been mentioned is that for some carriers you have to a reverse-lookup(able) domain. So if your <code>mail()</code> function sends your email from a domain that is not your mail server you must make sure the lookup will return your mailing server.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26583"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>

       <li id="comment-26795" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=63990aab4c9382ac48aacdf302ed3c05&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          Callum
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Hey guys just a heads up, this only works in a couple of countries other than the US because those countries CHARGE USERS FOR RECEIVING AN SMS. Many countries do not! So if you’re looking into this trying to find your gateway you probably won’t unless your in a country that charges to receive a text message.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-26795"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>

       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-27238" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=c4dca7b8e94c5b8d01873e08181439b1&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://sirestudios.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Tommy M.</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I created a simple function that makes it easy for app developers to notify users via a text. Here’s the link: <a href="http://forrst.com/posts/PHP_Function_to_Send_Text_Message-zlg" rel="nofollow">http://forrst.com/posts/PHP_Function_to_Send_Text_Message-zlg</a> Or look at this:<br> <code><br> function send_text_msg( $number , $carrier , $subject , $message )<br> {<br> global $setting;</code></p>
          <code> <p> $carrier_list = Array(<br> 'att' =&gt; 'txt.att.net',<br> 'verizon' =&gt; 'vtext.com',<br> 'tmobile' =&gt; 'tmomail.net',<br> 'sprint' =&gt; 'messaging.sprintpcs.com',<br> 'nextel' =&gt; 'messaging.nextel.com'<br> );</p> <p> return mail( $number.'@'.$carrier_list[$carrier] , $subject , $message , "From: ".$setting['company']." ");<br> }</p> </code>
          <p><code>// Send it<br> send_text_msg( '5551234567' , 'verizon' , 'New Notification!' , 'Jim has updated your project. Go ahead and login to see the changes made.' );<br> </code></p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-27238"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>

       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-27870" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=9ec4529661293b8db2897a0355634bd7&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://www.talking-autism.com/" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Carl Parry</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Hi,<br> Just wanted to say the script works here in South Africa (MTN).</p> 
          <p>Just substitute the AT&amp;T with the cell number in <a href="mailto:xxxxxxxxxx@sms.co.za">xxxxxxxxxx@sms.co.za</a></p> 
          <p>It’s free but it can take up to an hour to get through.</p> 
          <p>Cheers,<br> Carl.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-27870"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-31841" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=e6f572692d57c6c57dd340d7eca5c66a&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://pligg.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">Eric Heikkinen</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>After seeing this post I was considering writing a script to integrate into a CMS for the purposes of verifying people. I ended up deciding not to follow through with the idea, but I’d like to share some code that I came up with so that it wasn’t a complete waste of time.</p> 
          <p>What I wrote are 2 files. The first file contains a form where you select your mobile carrier from a drop-down list, then you enter your mobile phone number into a text field and hit submit. This sends the data via POST to the second file which will use the carrier and number data to try to send a message using the SMS Gateway.</p> 
          <p>I didn’t complete all of the global carrier options for the drop down selection area, but I did finish entering in American and Canadian providers. If anyone wants to take this file and either finish it or re-purpose it, you have my blessing.</p> 
          <p>Download zip: <a href="http://www.filedropper.com/mobile_2" rel="nofollow">http://www.filedropper.com/mobile_2</a><br> Pastebin form.php: <a href="http://pastebin.com/4Fqh7YJR" rel="nofollow">http://pastebin.com/4Fqh7YJR</a><br> Pastebin text.php: <a href="http://pastebin.com/WHkUrSLh" rel="nofollow">http://pastebin.com/WHkUrSLh</a></p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-31841"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <ul class="children"> 
        <li id="comment-499273" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=3dbc60a70e2d1ae8a26a4fcfe9892ac7&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
         <div class="box">
          <div class="comment-user">
           Brian
          </div>
          <div class="comment-content">

       <li id="comment-32494" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=c37ef23d7edc4460a610c7c8ce6e01e5&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          charley hankins
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>That’s all very well and good. However, when a person starts receiving harassing texts from an anonymous source, that is not cool. And there appears to be no way to trace where the call is coming from. We have called AT&amp;T and filed police reports. If you would like to help, please discover a means of tracing them.</p>

       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-33238" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=c1714bf6ba21af62f6f3c4b2b9ffc2db&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          Michael
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Does it applicable in Malaysia carrier ?</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-33238"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>

         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Hi,<br> Using this code:</p> 
          <p>mail(“1231231231@vtext.com”, “”, “This is the message text”, “From: <a href="mailto:jamestellerton@yahoo.com">jamestellerton@yahoo.com</a>\r\n”);</p> 
          <p>The text message arrives at the phone, but the From is not James Tellerton. Instead it is the name of the hosting account that the PHP is running on. Any ideas how to make the From work as intended?</p>

       <li id="comment-66659" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=46a777a49f545e3e4d27681cd2fabfda&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          <a href="http://www.google.com" rel="external nofollow" class="url">kiruba</a>
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>I am kiruba.I did not get one output in chat.if we give the username and message it will not display on the window.only display the username.i give a select query for this.</p> 
          <pre class="php">
&lt;?php 
session_start();
include('connect.php');
print_r($_SESSION);
if(isset($_SESSION['username']))
{
	//echo $_SESSION['username']= 'username';
	echo $username=$_SESSION['username'];
  $id=$_SESSION['user_id'];
//$msg=$_POST['message'];
 //$query = mysql_query("SELECT 'user_id' FROM tbl_message,tbl_users WHERE  'user_id' ='.$id.'");
//echo $query;
$query=mysql_query("SELECT 'user_id' FROM tbl_message, tbl_users WHERE 'user_id' = '.$id.'");

while($row = mysql_fetch_array($query))
{
	echo "$row[username]:$row[message]";
	
}
}

?&gt;
</pre> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-66659"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>

       <li id="comment-503472" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=832b47cc1218c919cf9f7868e348ece2&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">

         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-505760" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=e63a50a287e794a31203c5f0eb4c2ab8&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          Klaus Donnert
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>The biggest problem with email to sms is that both email and sms are low priority network traffic. Sometimes the delay can be 30 minutes to deliver email to sms messages, or the message may be dropped altogether. Twilio (sms to sms over web via their api) is a better choice at US $0.0075(as of this writing) per message. Even Twilio can sometimes be delayed several minutes, but not like email to sms.</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-505760"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>
       <!-- #comment-## --> 
       <li id="comment-508834" data-avatar="//gravatar.com/avatar.php?gravatar_id=8b6a43519783036683a241141c359f41&amp;size=48&amp;rating=G&amp;default=https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/themes/punky/images/anon.jpg">
        <div class="box">
         <div class="comment-user">
          Faysal
         </div>
         <div class="comment-content">
          <p>Can anyone please provide me Bangladesh Cellular networks Email to SMS Gateway??</p> 
         </div>
         <div class="comment-controls">
          <a href="#comment-508834"><i class="fa fa-bookmark" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
         </div>
        </div></li>

    <p><span>© David Walsh 2007-2017. All code <a href="http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT" rel="nofollow">MIT license</a>.</span><span>Hosting by <a href="http://dwf.tw/mt" rel="nofollow">Media Temple</a>.</span></p>
   </div>
  </footer>
